image-wrap.label: Figure 1
image-wrap.caption: Left: typical well log from the northern part of West Salym. Centre: injection (blue circles) and production (green/brown circles) WS daily rate bubble map (centre). ASP pilot location marked with black rectangular. Right: pilot well configuration with the nearest water injector and producer. Initial reservoir pressure distribution inside the pilot pattern is illustrated by the background gradient.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Left: typical well log from the northern part of West Salym. Centre: injection (blue circles) and production (green/brown circles) WS daily rate bubble map (centre). ASP pilot location marked with black rectangular. Right: pilot well configuration with the nearest water injector and producer. Initial reservoir pressure distribution inside the pilot pattern is illustrated by the background gradient.

image-wrap.label: Figure 2
image-wrap.caption: (a)-vertical porosity distribution from the open-hole logs of the pilot wells. (b)-vertical permeability and remaining oil saturation distribution from the open- and cased-hole logs for the observation well (OW).

formatted-caption.caption-text: (a)-vertical porosity distribution from the open-hole logs of the pilot wells. (b)-vertical permeability and remaining oil saturation distribution from the open- and cased-hole logs for the observation well (OW).

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: vertical porosity distribution from the open-hole logs of the pilot wells.
vertical permeability and remaining oil saturation distribution from the open- and cased-hole logs for the observation well (OW).

image-wrap.label: Figure 3
image-wrap.caption: (a) - IFT measurements with Salym crude oil for the pilot formulation with varying levels of NaCl. (b) phase behavior experiments with injected and produced samples of ASP solution. Extra NaCl was added for salinity scanning.

formatted-caption.caption-text: (a) - IFT measurements with Salym crude oil for the pilot formulation with varying levels of NaCl. (b) phase behavior experiments with injected and produced samples of ASP solution. Extra NaCl was added for salinity scanning.

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: IFT measurements with Salym crude oil for the pilot formulation with varying levels of NaCl
phase behavior experiments with injected and produced samples of ASP solution. Extra NaCl was added for salinity scanning.

image-wrap.label: Figure 4
image-wrap.caption: Concentration of chemicals, viscosity and filtration ratio during the injection of ASP slug. Note that in total 1.6 PV of ASP was injected by pilot wells while it is assumed that only quarter of this volume is injected inside the pilot pattern.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Concentration of chemicals, viscosity and filtration ratio during the injection of ASP slug. Note that in total 1.6 PV of ASP was injected by pilot wells while it is assumed that only quarter of this volume is injected inside the pilot pattern.

image-wrap.caption: (a) wellbore storage constant C color coded with the pre-shut-in rate and corresponding fracture size for IW1 until January 10th 2018. (b) viscosity and wellhead pressure of IW1 since September 2017.

formatted-caption.caption-text: (a) wellbore storage constant C color coded with the pre-shut-in rate and corresponding fracture size for IW1 until January 10th 2018. (b) viscosity and wellhead pressure of IW1 since September 2017.

image-wrap.caption: (a) - recovery ofpassive tracers from the producing well PW injected during pre-flush (stage 1) and (b)- during ASP injection with the nearest off-set producing wells switched off (stage 2).

image-wrap.label: Figure 8
image-wrap.caption: Injection logging (warm back and spinner) surveys in pilot wells: IW1, IW2, IW3 andIW4

formatted-caption.caption-text: Injection logging (warm back and spinner) surveys in pilot wells: IW1, IW2, IW3 andIW4

image-wrap.label: Figure 9
image-wrap.caption: Saturation Logging in observation well. Blue - decrease in oil saturation, brown - increase in oil saturation compared to base open hole induction log in April 2014. Left plot - CO log; Right plot - resistivity (NEK) log.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Saturation Logging in observation well. Blue - decrease in oil saturation, brown - increase in oil saturation compared to base open hole induction log in April 2014. Left plot - CO log; Right plot - resistivity (NEK) log.

image-wrap.label: Figure 10
image-wrap.caption: Production data for central producing (left column) and sampling (right column) wells. Upper row: monthly-averaged oil production rate (red lines) and weekly averaged water cut data (blue markers). Middle row: weekly averaged carbonate (red line), bicarbonate (green line) concentrations and pH (black markers). Bottom row: weekly averaged surfactant (violet) and IBA (yellow) concentrations and viscosity (blue markers). Production disruptions due to ESP failures caused by the carbonate scaling are shown with grey rectangles.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Production data for central producing (left column) and sampling (right column) wells. Upper row: monthly-averaged oil production rate (red lines) and weekly averaged water cut data (blue markers). Middle row: weekly averaged carbonate (red line), bicarbonate (green line) concentrations and pH (black markers). Bottom row: weekly averaged surfactant (violet) and IBA (yellow) concentrations and viscosity (blue markers). Production disruptions due to ESP failures caused by the carbonate scaling are shown with grey rectangles.

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: Production data for central producing and sampling wells
Production data for central producing and sampling wells

image-wrap.label: Figure 11
image-wrap.caption: Oil outlet quality (BS&W) at the final stage separator in September-October 2016. When the back produced surfactant concentration reached 500 ppm, separation deteriorated significantly leading to high BS&W in the oil outlet.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Oil outlet quality (BS&W) at the final stage separator in September-October 2016. When the back produced surfactant concentration reached 500 ppm, separation deteriorated significantly leading to high BS&W in the oil outlet.

image-wrap.label: Figure 12
image-wrap.caption: Water outlet quality (OiW) at the final stage separator in September-October 2016. At low surfactant concentrations (~100ppm), water quality deteriorates to a about ~2000ppm. At about 500ppm surfactant, water quality deteriorates further.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Water outlet quality (OiW) at the final stage separator in September-October 2016. At low surfactant concentrations (~100ppm), water quality deteriorates to a about ~2000ppm. At about 500ppm surfactant, water quality deteriorates further.

image-wrap.label: Figure 13
image-wrap.caption: Laboratory separation of ASP emulsion after 1h at 60°C. Optimum of demulsifier concentration was 400500 ppm for 3300 ppm of surfactant (left). Samples taken from the ETU (right). From left to right: Inlet, oil outlet first separator, oil outlet second separator, water outlet first separator, water outlet second separator. Upper photo: 1 hour heating in laboratory at 55°C; the lower photo: 2 hours.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Laboratory separation of ASP emulsion after 1h at 60°C. Optimum of demulsifier concentration was 400500 ppm for 3300 ppm of surfactant (left). Samples taken from the ETU (right). From left to right: Inlet, oil outlet first separator, oil outlet second separator, water outlet first separator, water outlet second separator. Upper photo: 1 hour heating in laboratory at 55°C; the lower photo: 2 hours.

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: Optimum of demulsifier concentration was 400500 ppm for 3300 ppm of surfactant
